en.value: Learning conversational phrases for a variety of social contexts, navigating a meeting
I wanted to talk to you about…
In this unit we're going to learn some phrases and expressions that we use in different social situations. You'll find them really useful to engage in everyday conversations with English speakers!

In English, there are many words we can use as fillers in a conversation, for when we want to introduce a comment or even when we'd like to pause to consider our next words. Let's have a look at some of them:
Well, I went for a run in the morning.
Right, give me a call if you need me.
Right, give me a call if you need me.
We can use "right" to introduce a comment.
The reason I asked is because I want to go there next year.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
I [k]was[/k] [k]wondering[/k]. How much did your flights to Brazil cost?
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
The reason I [k]asked[/k] is because I want to go there next year.
"As I was saying..." and "anyway..." can be used similarly. We use them when we want to continue with what we were saying after an interruption.
As I was saying, we finally booked the tickets.
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
because I want to go there next year.
We can also say "I won't keep you" or "I won't keep you any longer" as a polite way of ending a conversation.
Well, I won't keep you any longer. See you soon!
Select the words in the correct order.
I'd better go. Nice to see you.
Listen to the audio. Select the most accurate statement.
Sarah is resuming what she was saying.
Let's have another look at the expressions we've learned.
I'd better go. Nice to see you.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
So, how was your holiday, Olivia?
Amazing, Brazil is a great country.
I'd love to go there! [k]I was wondering[/k], how much did your flights cost?
They weren't as expensive as I thought. I got a very good deal.
[k]The reason[/k] I asked is because I want to go there next year.
You should definitely go. [k]As I was saying[/k], it's a great country, there are so many things to see...
I'll put it on my list then. Right, I'll let you [k]get on[/k]. Nice to see you!
Select all the words we use as fillers in a conversation.
I'd better go. Nice to see you.
[h]Right[/h], give me a call if you need me.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
The r[k]e[/k][k]a[/k]s[k]o[/k][k]n[/k] I ask[k]e[/k][k]d[/k] is because I want to go there next year.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
I was [k]wondering[/k]. Could I work from home tomorrow?
Complete the sentence to end the conversation politely.
[k]I'd better[/k] go. Nice to see you!
Olivia carries on with what she was saying after being interrupted.
[k]W[/k][k]e[/k][k]l[/k][k]l[/k], I got up really early because I was catching a train.
Complete the sentence explaining why you asked about something.
The [k]reason I asked[/k] is because I want to go there next year.
Imagine you have to speak to a co-worker about organising a company outing. How would you start the conversation and what would you say next?
Hi, I wanted to talk to you about ... / I think we should ... / What ...?

There will always be times when we need to ask someone to repeat something, whether it’s because we didn’t hear what they said, or because we need to ask for clarification. So that we’re prepared to do just that, we’re going to learn some useful phrases for asking for repetition or clarification.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Select the phrase you hear in the audio.
As you can see, we use all these phrases to ask for clarification or repetition. You can also simply say:
Listen to the audio. Select the question you hear.
Could you speak a little louder?
She wants him to repeat what he said.
She wants him to explain his point differently.
She disagrees with what he said.
Match the beginning and the end of the sentences.
Have another look at all the expressions we've learned.
Alyssa from upstairs and Carter from downstairs.
I said “Are you ready to leave in half an hour?”
In half an hour!? [k]What do you mean?[/k] What time does Samira’s barbecue start, again?
[k]I’m not sure I follow[/k]… Why do we need to leave at 4?
Because we need to go to the shop on the way, to pick up some things for the barbecue.
Oh right! OK I’ll get ready.
When are you likely to use the question you hear?
When you don't hear what someone says.
When you are sorry for something.
Select all the words we can use to ask for clarification.
When you are trying to understand someone, you might ask someone to speak...
[k]I'm not sure I follow.|I'm not sure I follow|I am not sure I follow[/k]
Type one of the expressions we've learned.
Fill in the gap using the image.

Whether we're having a meeting at work or organising something with our friends, being able to navigate a conversation is essential. 
Here are some of the expressions we're going to learn:
to be in charge of something
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
I took some notes from the meeting.
to be in charge of something
Who was in charge of the shop yesterday?
She's in charge of the staff.
I wanted to talk to you about...
I wanted to talk to you about next weekend.
She wanted to talk to you about the exam.
This sentence asks for someone's opinion.
This means: "She wanted to talk to you about the exam."
I think that we need some extra staff.
Instead of "I think", we can also use "In my opinion". It is a slightly more formal and polite way of expressing how we feel about something.
In my opinion, the first draft was better.
I think the third option works well, too.
Complete the sentence to express an opinion.
In my [k]opinion[/k], the manager is responsible for this project.
Select the words you can use to express your opinion.

alternative_values: We are running out of time.

en.value: Do you have anything to add?
This means the meeting is running ahead of time.
This means that there's not much time left.
To suggest a change of subject we can also say "What's next?".
To sum up, everyone is responsible for keeping the kitchen clean.
This is what we say when we have a question.
We say this to find out if other people want to ask a question.
Select the phrase we can use to summarise something.
Let's sum up the main points.
Let's divide the sum by three.
Let's have another look at all the words we've learned before we practise some more:
to be in charge of something
I wanted to talk to you about...
Do you have anything to add?
You need to speak to a co-worker. How might you open the conversation?
I wanted to talk to you about something.
I talked to you about it already.
I have to think about this first.
Complete the sentence to talk about responsibility.
Match the beginning and the end of each sentence.
How might we ask a colleague for his opinion?
Your colleague talks about his opinion. How does he start?
What else can we say for "I think..."?
Match each question with the context we might use it in.
Checking if something hasn't been mentioned.
The two of you recap the conversation. Fill in the missing words!
Just to [k]sum[/k] [k]up[/k]: I will be in charge of the cooking and you'll take care of the cleaning.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
I'd like to speak to the person [k]in charge of[/k] this shop, please.
I [k]wanted to talk to you[/k] about next weekend.
Listen to the audio. Which statement is true?
The meeting is coming to an end.
Complete the sentence to state your opinion.
[k]In my opinion|I think that|I think[/k] it's best to book the hotel in advance.
